Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Converging COVID-19, environment, health, and equity

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: Environmental engineering and science is a highly diverse field that uses knowledge of physics, chemistry, and biology to help protect human and ecological health. Many environmental engineers and scientists are doing research on COVID-19 to better understand of how to control the spread of the disease, as well as providing safe food and drinking water. The goal of this project is to hold a series of virtual meetings over six weeks bringing together researchers to discuss their work on COVID-19 in an integrated manner. They will also explore how inequities influence the outcomes and impact of their work. Benefits to society resulting from this work result from open source learning materials that show how different environments link to each other during the pandemic, and how to address inequities in society to come up with better solutions for sustainable communities. This meeting will feature a diverse representation of environmental engineering and science researchers. To maximize impact, the meeting will be open to anyone in the world, and all recordings will be shared on websites and over social media.<br/><br/>The goal of this project is to host a series of meetings bringing together researchers from environmental engineering and science and related fields to share knowledge and discuss interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary linkages as they relate to COVID-19 and the need for developing more healthy, just, and equitable societies. The themes for the proposed sessions will align COVID-19 and the Grand Challenges for Environmental Engineering in the 21st Century as outlined in the National Academies of Sciences Engineering, and Medicine (NASEM) study which include: (1) sustainably supplying food, energy, and water, (2) creating efficient, healthy, and resilient cities, (3) designing a future without pollution and waste, (4) climate change mitigation and adaptation, and (5) fostering informed decisions and actions. The meeting presents a new model of participation in a combined asynchronous and synchronous multimedia online learning environment. Presenters will be selected to reflect the diversity of the Nation, with particular effort made to recruit presenters who are currently underrepresented in STEM. Early career post-doctoral researchers and assistant professors will be presenters and session chairs to foster career development. Participants will be encouraged to register for the certificate portion of the meeting which requires the successful completion of six quizzes related to each session. A manuscript based on the meeting will be submitted to the journal of Environmental Engineering and Science to share best practices for virtual format for meetings and the convergence of environmental engineering and science through COVID-19.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project between the University of South Florida and the University of California Merced, ?Converging COVID-19, environment, health, and equity,? hosted a meeting that brought together researchers from environmental engineering and science, and related fields to share knowledge, and discuss linkages and similarities from domains of air, water, food, and the built environment as they relate to COVID-19 responses, and contexts of inequity within communities. Six 1.5 hour online sessions were held over six weeks in Fall 2020 along six themes of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine?s environmental engineering grand challenges for the 21st Century. An additional ?Youth Moving Forward? session was held in Spring 2021. The meeting included a new model of online conferences that was divided over six weeks instead of consecutive days for greater inclusivity of working parents. All sessions were recorded and included close captioning and sign language interpretation. We ensured conference presenters and moderators reflected the diversity of the U.S. population and included more junior researchers for their professional development.  

The conference had 30 faculty (majority Civil and Environmental Engineering and Environmental Sciences but some public health and humanities) at various stages in their career (Assistant, Associate, and Full) present five-minute talks along with one faculty and/or distinguished moderator for the hour-long discussion and question and answer session. There were 625 participants registered by the end of the conference. The number of unique viewers for sessions 1-6 were 190, 189, 138, 137, 156, and 130 respectively.  These viewers attended the conference from a total of 21 different countries (The Bahamas, Bangladesh, Barbados, Brazil, Canada, China, Costa Rica, Denmark, Germany, India, Jamaica, Malaysia, Mexico, Namibia, Nigeria, Singapore, Sweden, Trinidad and Tobago, Turkey, the United Kingdom, and the United States). Based on conference participant feedback, we added a Youth Moving Forward session for greater inclusion of youth. The youth session had 84 registrants and 44 attendees. Thirty-two certificates were awarded to conference participants who watched all six sessions and passed all session quizzes with greater than 80% (mostly undergraduate and graduate students and some industry professionals as well as post docs and faculty). All six sessions are available on YouTube for viewing later as well as shorter, five-minute videos for most of the speakers.

The conference provided opportunities for research. At UC Merced, an undergraduate environmental engineering student (woman) was supported for over a year and a half. The project also provided summer research fellowships to two other undergraduate environmental engineers (one woman of color and one Hispanic male). The undergraduate supported for 1.5 years took leadership for the conference quizzes and certificates and manuscript and lead the Youth Moving Forward Session. The project also supported construction of a Corsi-Rosenthal air filter that was placed at a local elementary school to reduce the spread of COVID-19 and improve indoor air quality. Outside of students directly supported on the grant and involved in conference organization, 32 students, post-docs, or faculty watched all six session and completed all six quizzes with over 80% average to receive a conference certificate. So far the project has resulted in one peer reviewed publication and two pre-prints. Results were also disseminated through two presentations to environmental engineering and science professional societies in summer 2021.
